contentItem.text: There are other species of kookaburra – the blue-winged and the spangled – but the laughing kookaburra has that distinct rolling, laughing call that is one of the best-known sounds in the animal world. The laughing kookaburras laugh it up and then go to sleep (roost) in the treetops at dusk. Just as dawn breaks, they wake everyone up with their wild laughter. They use this call to advertise their territory and tell others to stay out.

Laughing kookaburras eat snakes, mice, insects, and frogs that they catch. The parent birds often give small snakes to the chicks to teach them to hunt. The kookaburra can keep its head perfectly still while its body sways on a branch. They sit and wait for prey to be near then swoop down and grab it - swallowing their dinner whole!

Laughing kookaburras live in Eastern Australia, southern parts of Western Australia, and have been introduced to Tasmania. They prefer to live inland, away from the ocean, in the dry forest near a stream.

Wedge-tailed eagles, brown goshawks, owls, foxes, and grey butcherbirds all prey on the laughing kookaburras. If a kookaburra doesn't have time to fly away, it fluffs up its feathers in order to look bigger and to scare off a predator.

Laughing kookaburra parents keep the same nesting territory for life! The older young help by incubating the eggs, keeping the chicks warm, feeding their sisters and brothers, and defending their parents' territory. They leave home at 4 or 5 years old to find their own territory.
